question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a prolonged episode of coughing that started 30 minutes ago. His mother says her son was playing with some new toys, including a squirt gun, a robot, and some plastic building blocks he got for his birthday when the symptoms began. The coughing lasted several minutes, after which he was crying but could be soothed by his mother. He is otherwise healthy and his immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and babbles. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 139/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 96/47 mm Hg. The oropharynx is clear and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a prolonged episode of coughing that started 30 minutes ago. His mother says her son was playing with some new toys, including a squirt gun, a robot, and some plastic building blocks he got for his birthday when the symptoms began. The coughing lasted several minutes, after which he was crying but could be soothed by his mother. He is otherwise healthy and his immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and babbles. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 139/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 96/47 mm Hg. The oropharynx is clear and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
hint: The foreign body this patient has ingested is thin, circular, and shows a double-rim (halo) on chest x-ray which indicates that it is a button battery.
learning_objective: Recognize button battery ingestion, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Administration of ipecac as an emetic is not recommended as treatment for toxic ingestion. There is insufficient evidence to support that syrup of ipecac improves outcomes in cases of poisoning. Moreover, its side effects, such as lethargy, complicate diagnosis.

answers.content: Removal of the foreign body with magnet and nasogastric tube
answers.explanation_why: Removal of the battery with a magnet and nasogastric tube would not allow visualization of the esophageal mucosa and any injury that may be present.

Reassurance and observation would be inappropriate in this case. The alkali material in this battery, which is lodged in the esophagus, can cause chemical burns and injury of the mucosa 2 hours after ingestion, even in an asymptomatic patient.

Conservative management can be considered if the battery is located in the bowel and the patient is asymptomatic. In this patient with a button battery in an esophageal location, treatment should not be delayed because of the risk of caustic injury from the battery.

Chelation therapy can be used to manage metal poisoning. While ingestion of a battery containing mercury can elevate blood mercury levels, this patient does not have any symptoms of mercury toxicity, such as intention tremor, ataxia, or psychiatric disturbances.

Emergency endoscopic removal is necessary for all ingested batteries that become lodged in the esophagus. Because alkali material leaking from the battery may cause severe chemical burns 2 hours after ingestion, removal is necessary regardless of whether the patient is symptomatic or not. Removal should not be delayed, even if the patient has eaten. Endoscopic removal allows visualization and assessment of any tissue damage. The position of the negative pole of the battery should also be assessed during endoscopy. The negative pole causes the most severe necrotic injury. Possible complications of a mucosal injury include tracheal stenosis, tracheomalacia, fistula, perforation, and mediastinitis.

images.title: Button battery impaction in esophagus
images.description: X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a young childA well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body is seen behind the trachea in the upper esophagus. On close inspection, a double rim (dashed lines), or halo (green overlay), is visible on the PA view, which indicates that it is a button battery. A step-off (arrows) to the small diameter anode (hatched green overlay) is seen on the lateral view.Recognition of a button battery in the esophagus is a pediatric emergency. Radiographs can frequently differentiate button batteries from similarly sized coins and ascertain the direction of the anode, where the most severe damage from the battery occurs. The anode step-off (arrows) may not be visible on some very thin batteries.

question_text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening shortness of breath with walking. He has not had any cough, fevers, or recent weight loss. He has hypercholesterolemia, for which he takes simvastatin, but otherwise is healthy. For 35 years he has worked for a demolition company. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. The patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening shortness of breath with walking. He has not had any cough, fevers, or recent weight loss. He has hypercholesterolemia, for which he takes simvastatin, but otherwise is healthy. For 35 years he has worked for a demolition company. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-expiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. The patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?
hint: Diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes together with pleural plaques is the classic presentation of asbestosis.
learning_objective: Recognize bronchogenic carcinoma associated with asbestosis and smoking.

answers.explanation_why: The risk of thyroid carcinoma is increased after neck radiation or in patients with MEN2 syndrome. Asbestosis is not a known risk factor for thyroid carcinoma.

Tuberculosis occurs more frequently in patients with silicosis. The main presenting symptom in silicosis is dyspnea and a cough, as in this patient. However, chest x-ray would typically show eggshell calcifications and bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities, which are both absent here.
Sarcoidosis is not associated with asbestosis, but rather with beryllium exposure.

images.title: Thoracic sarcoidosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view)The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

answers.explanation_why: Asbestosis is the main etiological factor of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. Although the risk of mesothelioma is markedly increased in this patient, another complication is more likely to arise.

Bronchogenic carcinoma is the most common malignant pulmonary tumor in patients with asbestosis and the second most common carcinoma worldwide. This patient has two important risk factors, namely a smoking history and a history of asbestos exposure. The first symptom of bronchogenic carcinoma is usually a cough, although hemoptysis, dyspnea and chest pain can also occur.

Asbestosis is the main cause of mesothelioma, which rarely occurs without a history of asbestos exposure. However, bronchogenic carcinoma is still vastly more common than mesothelioma, even in people with a history of asbestos exposure.

question_text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a photosensitive blistering rash on her hands, forearms, and face for 3 weeks. The lesions are not itchy. She has also noticed that her urine has been dark brown in color recently. Twenty years ago, she was successfully treated for Coats disease of the retina via retinal sclerotherapy. She is currently on hormonal replacement therapy for perimenopausal symptoms. Her aunt and sister have a history of similar skin lesions. Examination shows multiple fluid-filled blisters and oozing erosions on the forearms, dorsal side of both hands, and forehead. There is hyperpigmented scarring and patches of bald skin along the sides of the blisters. Laboratory studies show a normal serum ferritin concentration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to induce remission in this patient?
content_preview: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a photosensitive blistering rash on her hands, forearms, and face for 3 weeks. The lesions are not itchy. She has also noticed that her urine has been dark brown in color recently. Twenty years ago, she was successfully treated for Coats disease of the retina via retinal sclerotherapy. She is currently on hormonal replacement therapy for perimenopausal symptoms. Her aunt and sister have a history of similar skin lesions. Examination shows multiple fluid-filled blisters and oozing erosions on the forearms, dorsal side of both hands, and forehead. There is hyperpigmented scarring and patches of bald skin along the sides of the blisters. Laboratory studies show a normal serum ferritin concentration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to induce remission in this patient?
hint: This woman has a photosensitive blistering rash associated with chronic skin changes and brown discoloration of the urine. These findings are typical of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial therapy for porphyria cutanea tarda.

answers.explanation_why: Liver transplantation could address the etiology of PCT, the insufficiency of hepatic enzyme uroporphyrinogen-III decarboxylase. However, liver transplantation would be inappropriate in this case because of the availability of other noninvasive therapies that are highly effective.

Though there is limited evidence that thalidomide may reduce the production of porphyrins, thalidomide is not a primary therapy for PCT. There are other therapeutic approaches that are more effective.

Phlebotomy is an effective treatment for inducing remission of PCT and is the preferred initial therapy for patients with and without iron overload. It works by reducing hepatic iron stores, which in turn reduces the accumulation of porphyrins. Following remission, routine phlebotomy may be necessary to prevent recurrence of symptoms. Hydroxychloroquine is also an effective treatment for inducing remission of PCT, but contraindications (e.g., history of retinal disease) should be considered. Iron-chelating agents, such as deferoxamine, may also be indicated if phlebotomy is inadequate. In addition to induction of remission, select patients should receive genetic testing and counseling, particularly if they have a family history of PCT, as is likely in this patient. Regular measures for sun protection and avoidance of precipitating factors (e.g., exogenous estrogen use) should also be practiced.

Hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment for inducing remission of porphyria cutanea tarda. It works by forming water-soluble complexes with porphyrins, which the kidneys can then excrete. However, there is a risk of retinal damage with hydroxychloroquine treatment, and it is contraindicated in patients with a history of retinal disease, as in this patient. Additional contraindications to hydroxychloroquine use include advanced liver and renal disease and psoriasis (which may flare with hydroxychloroquine treatment).

Iron-chelating agents, including deferoxamine, can induce remission of porphyria cutanea tarda through the reduction of hepatic iron stores, which reduces the accumulation of porphyrins. However, they are less effective than phlebotomy and thus are typically only used in patients who cannot tolerate phlebotomy or have poor venous access.

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a rash on his neck and back for the past 6 hours. He says that he first noticed some reddening of the skin on his back the previous evening, which turned into a blistering, red rash overnight. He went surfing the previous day and spent 5 hours at the beach. He reports having applied at least 1 oz of water-resistant SPF 30 sunscreen 30 minutes before leaving his home. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema of the skin over the upper back and dorsum of the neck, with 3 vesicles filled with clear fluid. The affected area is edematous and tender to touch. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms in the future?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a rash on his neck and back for the past 6 hours. He says that he first noticed some reddening of the skin on his back the previous evening, which turned into a blistering, red rash overnight. He went surfing the previous day and spent 5 hours at the beach. He reports having applied at least 1 oz of water-resistant SPF 30 sunscreen 30 minutes before leaving his home. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema of the skin over the upper back and dorsum of the neck, with 3 vesicles filled with clear fluid. The affected area is edematous and tender to touch. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms in the future?
hint: This patient has a painful, erythematous rash with blisters, which developed on sun-exposed areas after a day at the beach. This is typical of a sunburn.
learning_objective: Recognize the cause of sunburn, and choose the appropriate sun protection behavior to prevent recurrence.

answers.explanation_why: To provide adequate protection against sunburn, sunscreen with an adequate sun protection factor (SPF) should be applied at least 30 minutes prior to sun exposure and again after each exposure to water or after sweating. This patient's sunburn is likely due to the fact that he did not reapply sunscreen at any point during the 5 hours he was surfing. Even if this patient had not been swimming or surfing, sunscreen should be reapplied every 2–3 hours to prevent sunburn.

answers.content: Apply sunscreen directly before getting into water
answers.explanation_why: Sunscreen should be applied 30 minutes before sun exposure, which this patient did do. Additionally, sunscreen should often be applied several minutes before exposure to water to prevent the immediate washing off of the product.

Sun protection factor (SPF) 50 sunscreen provides only a negligible 1% increase in sun protection compared to the SPF 30 used by the patient, which already provides 97% protection. There are other factors concerning the application of sunscreen that contributed more to this patient's sunburn.

answers.content: Only go outside on cloudy days
answers.explanation_why: Cloud coverage does not provide adequate protection from ultraviolet (UV) radiation, and sunscreen should still be applied on cloudy days. Additional risk factors that increase risk of sunburn include UV reflection off of water and sand, which is likely to occur at the beach, as well as snow. UV radiation is also more intense at higher altitudes.

answers.content: Apply at least 3 oz of sunscreen
answers.explanation_why: For most nonobese adults, 1 oz of sunscreen is sufficient to adequately cover skin and provide sufficient sun protection.

Sunscreen that is “water resistant” or “very water resistant” can provide sun protection for up to 40 or 80 minutes, respectively. The terms “waterproof” or “sweatproof” can no longer be used to market sunscreens, as sunscreen must always be reapplied after the specified period of time to prevent sunburn.

question_text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's hands show signs of frostbite following prolonged exposure to the cold.
learning_objective: Recognize frostbite, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Debridement may be indicated in the management of frostbite. While this patient's hands show features of frostbite, surgical treatment with debridement or amputation should not be performed until all nonviable tissue becomes clearly demarcated, a process that usually takes 3–4 weeks.

answers.content: Intra-arterial administration of tissue plasminogen activator
answers.explanation_why: Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), in combination with heparin, is indicated in the treatment of frostbite in patients without contraindications for anticoagulation therapy. tPA acts to prevent vascular thrombosis in frostbitten tissue, but it is usually reserved for patients at high risk for a life-altering amputation. This patient has cyanosis of the distal phalanges only, which will likely be treated with a soft-tissue amputation, or no amputation at all. A different step in management is more urgent at this time.

Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid is indicated to treat individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). Since this patient is only borderline hypothermic, passive rewarming measures (e.g., removing wet clothing, warm room) are sufficient and IV crystalloid infusion is not required.

Extracorporeal blood rewarming may be used to manage individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). While it is the most effective method of active rewarming, it is an invasive procedure associated with a number of risks (e.g., hemorrhages, stroke) and is reserved for management of the most severe cases. This patient would benefit from passive rewarming measures (e.g., warm clothing, blankets) but does not require treatment for severe hypothermia.

In an individual with frostbite, treatment with intravenous antibiotics and sterile dressings is indicated to manage bacterial superinfections. Since this patient shows no signs of infection (e.g., localized swelling, erythema, fever, leukocytosis), antibiotic treatment is not required.

answers.content: Immersion of affected extremities in warm water
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with suspected frostbite, active rewarming of the affected extremity is indicated to avoid further tissue damage. The affected extremity should be immersed in a warm (preferably 37–39°C), circulating water bath. Passive rewarming is also helpful (especially in patients with mild hypothermia) and includes removing any wet clothes, covering with blankets, and increasing the temperature of the room.

In patients with concomitant moderate-to-severe hypothermia, treatment of hypothermia should take priority because it can be acutely life-threatening. The trunk should be warmed prior to the extremities, as peripheral vasodilation may lead to a return of cold blood to the heart, which increases the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized pruritus and raised, erythematous plaques on the skin over his hands, chest, and legs for 6 hours. He reports having clear liquid discharge from his nose and sneezing. He says that his symptoms began suddenly the previous night, 30 minutes after he had dinner at a seafood restaurant. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past as well. Four months ago, he had an episode of narrow-angle glaucoma. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows clear, serous secretions, with edematous and erythematous mucosa and turbinates. Paranasal sinuses are not tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized pruritus and raised, erythematous plaques on the skin over his hands, chest, and legs for 6 hours. He reports having clear liquid discharge from his nose and sneezing. He says that his symptoms began suddenly the previous night, 30 minutes after he had dinner at a seafood restaurant. He has had similar symptoms occasionally in the past as well. Four months ago, he had an episode of narrow-angle glaucoma. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows clear, serous secretions, with edematous and erythematous mucosa and turbinates. Paranasal sinuses are not tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient presents with generalized pruritus, urticaria, rhinorrhea, and sneezing after intake of a specific food, all of which are consistent with a food-based allergic reaction. The patient's medical history should be taken into account before prescribing a medication.
learning_objective: Recognize contraindications of first-generation antihistamines, and choose an appropriate alternative for allergic reactions.

answers.explanation_why: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine commonly used to treat allergies (e.g., hay fever), pruritus, and nausea. While it would also be effective in treating this patient's food allergy, first-generation antihistamines have anticholinergic side effects that can cause mydriasis and trigger an acute attack in patients with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Therefore, diphenhydramine is contraindicated in this patient.

In an individual with rhinitis, amoxicillin can be indicated if underlying infectious rhinosinusitis is suspected. This patient, however, presents with symptoms indicating an allergic reaction and shows no further symptoms of a bacterial sinus infection (e.g., fever, purulent rhinitis, tenderness of paranasal sinuses).

Chlorpheniramine is a first-generation antihistamine commonly used to treat allergies (e.g., hay fever), as well as sinus congestion and rhinitis caused by upper respiratory infections. Although it would also be effective in treating this patient's food allergy, first-generation antihistamines have anticholinergic side effects that can cause mydriasis and trigger an acute attack in patients with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Therefore, chlorpheniramine is contraindicated in this patient.

First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) are largely used for the management of allergic reactions. However, this group of agents has anticholinergic side effects, such as mydriasis, which can induce acute angle-closure glaucoma in patients like this one with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Since first-generation antihistamines are contraindicated in this patient, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy is a second-generation antihistamine such as fexofenadine, which is similarly effective but has fewer sedative and anticholinergic side effects.

Calamine lotion is used for the topical treatment of mild to moderate pruritus in individuals with skin conditions such as varicella, sunburn, and xerosis. While it may alleviate some of this patient's pruritus, it is not effective in treating the underlying allergic reaction.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his chemistry teacher 20 minutes after being involved in a laboratory accident at his school. During the accident, the boy's right eye was exposed to potassium hydroxide. He has severe pain in his right eye and reports difficulty keeping the eye open. The boy states he was wearing his prescription glasses when the accident occurred and that, immediately after the accident, his eye was irrigated thoroughly with cold tap water for approximately 5 minutes by the teacher. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination of the right eye shows erythema and blistering of the skin over the eyelid, with conjunctival congestion and excessive tearing in the eye. There is a partial thickness laceration above the right eyebrow. Further examination is impeded due to marked blepharospasm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his chemistry teacher 20 minutes after being involved in a laboratory accident at his school. During the accident, the boy's right eye was exposed to potassium hydroxide. He has severe pain in his right eye and reports difficulty keeping the eye open. The boy states he was wearing his prescription glasses when the accident occurred and that, immediately after the accident, his eye was irrigated thoroughly with cold tap water for approximately 5 minutes by the teacher. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination of the right eye shows erythema and blistering of the skin over the eyelid, with conjunctival congestion and excessive tearing in the eye. There is a partial thickness laceration above the right eyebrow. Further examination is impeded due to marked blepharospasm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's clinical features (ocular pain, conjunctival congestion, excessive tearing, marked blepharospasm), which appeared after exposure to a caustic chemical, indicate a chemical ocular burn.
learning_objective: Recognize chemical ocular burn, and choose the most appropriate initial management step.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate and thorough irrigation with sterile normal saline (e.g, via a plastic scleral lens) following an ocular chemical burn is the most important step to prevent permanent vision loss. Immediate irrigation initiated by first responders should continue for at least 30–60 minutes or until the pH of the eye has normalized. This process can sometimes take 2–3 hours for alkaline compounds such as potassium hydroxide because they are lipophilic and thus penetrate tissue more quickly. This patient has ongoing symptoms after just 5 minutes of irrigation. Continued irrigation in the emergency department should therefore begin immediately. Once irrigation is completed and the pH has normalized, broad-spectrum topical antibiotics should be administered.

Broad-spectrum topical antibiotics such as erythromycin ointment should be given to all patients with severe chemical ocular burns and should also be administered to this patient. However, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Topical steroids such as prednisolone acetate can help reduce acute inflammation of the eye after chemical injuries. However, steroids might have a negative impact on reepithelialization and increase the risk of secondary infection. Thus, they should be used with caution and for a limited amount of time only. Furthermore, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Intravenous analgesics such as morphine can be administered to patients with severe pain that is not relieved by topical and non-opiate analgesics. However, they are not typically required for chemical ocular injuries. Furthermore, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Immobilization of the eye is indicated in the event of a closed-globe contusion, which is commonly caused by blunt force trauma. Although this patient's eyebrow laceration suggests possible blunt force trauma, addressing the chemical burn to the eye should be the first step in management. Furthermore, crossed bandaging after a chemical ocular burn could increase the risk of a symblepharon, thus leading to further complications.

answers.content: Begin irrigation with weak acidic solution
answers.explanation_why: Theoretically, acidic solutions can neutralize the alkaline pH of potassium hydroxide. However, attempting to neutralize exposure to alkaline agents by irrigation with acidic solutions, and vice versa, is not recommended because the neutralization reaction releases heat, which can cause further damage to the eye.

question_text:
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her family found her unresponsive. She lives alone in her apartment and had called her daughter to report several hours of nausea, headache, and worsening dizziness. The daughter says that she has been trying to convince her mother to move into an assisted living facility. She has been worrying about her mother's well-being since the beginning of the winter, especially because her mother's furnace has not been working properly recently. The patient has atrial fibrillation and depression. Current medications are warfarin, metoprolol succinate, and amitriptyline. She is awake but lethargic. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min and irregular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Examination shows a pale reddish coloration of the skin. Serum studies show a prothrombin time of 32.8 sec (INR = 2.5). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.30

PCO_2

37.8 mm Hg

PO_2

113 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

16 mEq/L

Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her family found her unresponsive. She lives alone in her apartment and had called her daughter to report several hours of nausea, headache, and worsening dizziness. The daughter says that she has been trying to convince her mother to move into an assisted living facility. She has been worrying about her mother's well-being since the beginning of the winter, especially because her mother's furnace has not been working properly recently. The patient has atrial fibrillation and depression. Current medications are warfarin, metoprolol succinate, and amitriptyline. She is awake but lethargic. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min and irregular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Examination shows a pale reddish coloration of the skin. Serum studies show a prothrombin time of 32.8 sec (INR = 2.5). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.30 PCO2 37.8 mm Hg PO2 113 mm Hg HCO3- 16 mEq/L Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Despite a normal PaO_2 on arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) and SpO_2 on pulse oximetry, this patient should be treated with oxygen.
learning_objective: Recognize carbon monoxide poisoning, and recall the diagnostic finding.

answers.explanation_why: Calcium oxalate crystals can be detected in urinalysis of patients following intoxication with ethylene glycol, a substance found in industrial products such as antifreeze solutions and windshield wiper fluid. Poisoning may occur due to ingestion as an ethanol substitute, as a suicide attempt or by accident. Clinical presentation includes an altered mental status and metabolic acidosis, as seen in this patient. Although this patient has a history of depression, which increases the risk of self-harm behavior, she lacks other key findings of ethylene glycol toxicity, including sweet-smelling breath, flank pain, hematuria, and tetany. Moreover, red discoloration of the skin is not typically associated with ethylene glycol poisoning.

answers.content: Focal parenchymal hypoattenuation on CT scan of the head
answers.explanation_why: A focal parenchymal hypoattenuation on a CT scan of the head can be seen in patients with acute ischemic stroke. This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which increases her risk of thromboembolic disease. Headache, nausea, dizziness, and impaired consciousness are possible symptoms of a cerebrovascular event. However, an ischemic stroke is unlikely in the setting of warfarin therapy with a therapeutic INR (2 to 3). Moreover, when an ischemic stroke occurs in a patient with a therapeutic INR, it is typically a lacunar infarct manifesting with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., hemiparesis), which is not seen here.

images.title: Acute ischemic stroke with hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

answers.explanation_why: An elevated serum cyanide blood concentration can be found in patients that have been exposed to combustion reactions of plastics, upholstery, rubber, and other nitrogen-containing products, most commonly as a result of house fires. Patients with cyanide poisoning can present very similarly to this patient, with nausea, headache, dizziness, altered mental status, skin flushing, and metabolic acidosis on ABG. However, cyanide poisoning is unlikely in this case as there is no history of a fire at the scene.

An elevated blood level of methemoglobin (MetHb) typically results from exposure to substances that increase intrinsic production of MetHb (e.g., nitrate-containing drinking water, certain drugs such as nitroglycerin, sulfonamides, and topical anesthetics). In methemoglobinemia, PaO_2 is often normal despite evidence of poor tissue oxygenation (i.e., metabolic acidosis), as the amount of dissolved O_2 in the blood is unchanged by the presence of MetHb. Likewise, SpO_2 will be normal if a standard pulse oximeter is used as those cannot differentiate between methemoglobin and oxyhemoglobin. Symptoms of methemoglobinemia include headache, nausea, dizziness, and lethargy, as seen here. However, it manifests with cyanosis rather than the skin redness seen in this case. Additionally, this patient has no history that suggests ingestion of precipitating agents.

Prolongation of the QRS complex on an electrocardiogram can be seen in individuals with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose. This patient has a history of depression, which increases her risk for suicide attempt with toxic ingestion of her prescribed TCA, amitriptyline. TCA toxicity can cause mental status changes, as well as skin flushing, as seen in this case. However, this patient lacks other common symptoms of TCA overdose, particularly findings of anticholinergic toxicity. Moreover, her initial symptoms of nausea, headache, and dizziness are not typically associated with TCA toxicity.

An elevated blood level of carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) confirms carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. CO is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas that can leak from a malfunctioning furnace. CO has a greater affinity for hemoglobin (Hb) than oxygen does, so when it binds to Hb it reduces Hb's oxygen-carrying capacity and shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left, thereby decreasing O_2 release in tissues. This leads to tissue hypoxia and metabolic acidosis, as seen here. Note that PaO_2 is normal as it reflects the amount of dissolved O_2 in the blood, which is not affected by CO. Likewise, SpO_2 will be normal if a standard pulse oximeter is used, as those cannot differentiate between COHb and oxyhemoglobin.

Symptoms of CO poisoning are variable and depend on the COHb level. Nausea, headache, and dizziness are common early signs. After exposure to high levels of CO, patients may develop a cherry-red skin tone, but this finding is more commonly seen postmortem. Treatment includes supportive care, 100% O_2, and occasionally hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

images.title: Oxygen dissociation curve for carbon monoxide poisoning
images.description: The pink line shows the normal change in blood oxygen content (O_2 bound to hemoglobin (Hb)) in the presence of increasing partial pressure of O_2 in arteries (P_aO_2). When carbon monoxide (CO) is bound to 50% of hemoglobin (green line), the maximal volume of O_2 bound to hemoglobin decreases and there is a left shift in the graph, reflecting the increase in O_2 affinity of hemoglobin.

question_text: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
content_preview: A healthy 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice on UV protection. She works as an archaeologist and is required to work outside for extended periods of time. She is concerned about premature skin aging. The physician recommends sun-protective clothing and sunscreen. In order to protect effectively against photoaging, the sunscreen should contain which of the following active ingredients?
hint: Sunscreens that provide protection against both ultraviolet A (UVA) and ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation are recommended to prevent premature aging of the skin.
learning_objective: Recall the active ingredients in sunscreen that protect against photoaging.

answers.explanation_why: Trolamine salicylate absorbs UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

TMP/SMX is used to treat numerous infections (i.e., UTI, acne vulgaris, toxoplasmosis, impetigo, cellulitis). Although it is effective against skin infections, the sulfonamide component causes photosensitivity and increases the risk of skin damage from UVA and UVB radiation.

Topical vitamin E can reduce skin damage from UVB radiation. However, it does not provide protection from UVA radiation and therefore would still leave this patient at risk for premature aging of the skin.
Para-aminobenzoic acid is only able to filter out UVB radiation. This patient would not be protected from UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

Mineral-based sunscreens (e.g., with zinc oxide, titanium oxide) are broad-spectrum sunscreens and provide full protection from UVA and UVB radiation by absorbing light in those spectrums, which prevents penetration into the dermis and premature aging of the skin. Sunscreens that have salicylates (e.g., trolamine salicylate), para-aminobenzoic acid, cinnamates (e.g., cinoxate), or octocrylene as the active ingredient can absorb UVB radiation but not UVA radiation, which can still cause premature aging of the skin.

question_text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, and swelling and pruritus of the lips, tongue, and throat for 1 hour. The symptoms began minutes after he started eating a lobster dinner. It is determined that his symptoms are due to surface crosslinking of IgE. This immunologic event most likely caused the release of which of the following?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, and swelling and pruritus of the lips, tongue, and throat for 1 hour. The symptoms began minutes after he started eating a lobster dinner. It is determined that his symptoms are due to surface crosslinking of IgE. This immunologic event most likely caused the release of which of the following?
hint: The patient's acute-onset abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, swelling, and pruritus after eating shellfish (a common allergen) are characteristic of an anaphylactic reaction. Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE on mast cells.
learning_objective: Recognize anaphylaxis, and recall the mediators released from mast cells.

answers.explanation_why:
In the immediate phase of anaphylactic reactions, surface crosslinking of IgE causes mast cell degranulation, which releases tryptase, histamine, heparin, and eosinophil chemotactic factors. Of these compounds, tryptase is a relatively specific marker of mast cell activation.

In the late phase of anaphylactic reactions, inflammatory cells (e.g., eosinophils) and cytokines mediate inflammation and tissue damage.

images.title: Mast cells
images.description: Photomicrograph of a blood smearMast cells are visible as multiple large purple cells containing copious amounts of cytoplasmic granules.

answers.explanation_why: Cathepsin is a lysosomal enzyme released by neutrophils during type III hypersensitivity reactions, as seen in vasculitides and serum sickness. Although serum sickness (or a serum-sickness like reaction) may present with urticaria, this patient lacks other characteristic findings such as fever, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, serum sickness typically occurs 1–2 weeks after antigen exposure (unlike this patient's acute-onset symptoms). Cathepsin is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.

Serotonin is released in high levels in carcinoid syndrome, which may present with abdominal pain and shortness of breath. However, carcinoid syndrome usually presents with additional symptoms, such as recurrent diarrhea and flushing. It does not cause facial swelling, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator responsible for facial swelling in patients with hereditary angioedema. In addition to facial swelling, some patients with hereditary angioedema also have gastrointestinal attacks that manifest with abdominal pain, similar to this patient. However, this condition does not cause urticaria or pruritus, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.
answers.explanation_but: Acquired causes of C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency and ACE inhibitor therapy (which decreases levels of ACE responsible for the breakdown of bradykinin) can also cause bradykinin-mediated angioedema.

answers.explanation_why: Interferon-gamma is secreted by natural killer cells and T cells and stimulates macrophages. This response occurs during type II hypersensitivity reactions and type IV hypersensitivity reactions. However, neither of these reactions play a role in anaphylaxis. Interferon-gamma is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.

question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
hint: The patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, and decreased DLCO raise suspicion for an interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, together with the upper lobe nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes, are characteristic of exposure to a substance classically associated with hard rock mining.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic silicosis, and recall its associated occupational exposure.

answers.explanation_why: Berylliosis is typically seen in patients working in high-tech sectors, such as the nuclear and aerospace industries, where beryllium alloys are common. While berylliosis also affects the upper lobes and would present similarly to this patient, histological analysis is characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas and a reticular interstitial pattern on chest x-ray similar to that of sarcoidosis.

This patient is suffering from chronic silicosis due to an occupational exposure to crystalline silica, as evidenced by the pathognomic biopsy findings that are consistent with a silicotic nodule. Radiographic abnormalities, such as diffuse ground glass or nodular opacities, can arise early in the disease (typically the upper lobes). However, overt symptoms can take decades of exposure to develop, which is consistent with this patient's advanced age.

Advanced silicosis patients are at particularly high risk for developing tuberculosis.

images.title: Silicosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspneaThere are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

answers.explanation_why: Exposure to thermophilic actinomyces spores in moldy hay can lead to a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, called Farmer's lung. This would also present with progressive dyspnea and chronic cough, but histology would instead reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells. Furthermore, chest x-ray would show ground-glass opacities with honeycombing, and in some cases, emphysema.

images.title: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
images.description: H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

answers.explanation_why: Chronic exposure to carbon dust can result in Coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Similar to this patient's condition, black lung results in small nodular opacities on chest x-ray, specifically in the upper lung fields. Histologic analysis, however, would instead show deposition of dark pigment in the interstitial tissue and hilar lymph nodes due to carbon accumulation in alveolar macrophages.

Exposure to asbestos fibers can lead to development of asbestosis later in life. While asbestosis also presents indolently with dyspnea and a chronic cough, the chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
hint: A history of painless hematuria, combined with the cystoscopic finding of bladder masses composed of atypical urothelial cells, is consistent with urothelial carcinoma.
learning_objective: Recognize urothelial carcinoma, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Exposure to ionizing radiation is associated with certain occupations, previous cancer treatments, and living environments (e.g., near nuclear power plants). It has been found to be associated with later development of papillary thyroid cancer, not bladder cancer.

A strong risk factor for urothelial cancer is prolonged exposure to aromatic amines like benzidine. These chemicals are especially associated with the rubber production, oil refining, and dye-making industries. Other risk factors for urothelial cancer include nicotine abuse, arsenic exposure, and cyclophosphamide use.

Nitrosamines are compounds formed from nitrites and amines and are found in certain foods like smoked meats. They have been found to be carcinogenic, but are most closely associated with the development of gastric cancer.

Aflatoxins are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus, which is a fungus that can grow on improperly stored nuts and rice. Although aflatoxins are carcinogenic, they have been primarily linked to hepatocellular carcinoma and not urothelial cancer.

Vinyl chloride is a chemical that especially plumbers are exposed to when working with polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes. Although vinyl chloride is carcinogenic, it has primarily been linked to liver angiosarcoma and not urothelial cancer. It also increases the risk of brain cancer, lung cancer, leukemia, and lymphoma.

Radon is a radioactive gas that forms as a byproduct from decay of uranium, thorium, and radium. Its concentration can be high in mines and poorly ventilated basements. Although it is the second leading cause of lung cancer, it is not associated with urothelial cancer.

question_text: A 63-year-old man is brought by his wife to the emergency department after he was found in their lakeside cabin with nausea, headache, and agitation 1 hour ago. When the wife left their cabin earlier in the day to get more firewood, the patient did not have any symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Neurologic examination shows confusion and orientation only to person and place. He recalls only one of three objects after 5 minutes. His gait is unsteady. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man is brought by his wife to the emergency department after he was found in their lakeside cabin with nausea, headache, and agitation 1 hour ago. When the wife left their cabin earlier in the day to get more firewood, the patient did not have any symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Neurologic examination shows confusion and orientation only to person and place. He recalls only one of three objects after 5 minutes. His gait is unsteady. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's current condition?
hint: This patient presents with nausea, headache, confusion, and short-term memory loss. These symptoms, together with a history of staying in an enclosed space with a gas or wood-burning stove or wood fire (commonly used in cabins during the winter), are consistent with the diagnosis of carbon monoxide (CO) toxicity. Patients with CO poisoning can have a normal SpO_2 because pulse oximetry cannot distinguish between carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) and oxyhemoglobin.
learning_objective: Recognize carbon monoxide poisoning, and choose the most effective intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Hydroxycobalamin is a cyanide-binding agent used to treat cyanide poisoning. Although patients with cyanide poisoning may present with altered mental status, headache, and nausea, cyanide poisoning is usually associated with vehicular fires, fires at plastics and rubber manufacturing factories, mining, and prolonged administration of sodium nitroprusside.

The mixture of helium and oxygen (heliox) is often used for diseases that cause profound airflow limitation (e.g. croup, bronchiolitis, asthma). The mixture has lower density than room air and is therefore more likely to retain laminar flow in central airways and elicit less effort to breathe than room air. Decreasing the density would not facilitate the clearance of carbon monoxide or improve the patient's oxygenation.

Patients with suspected carbon monoxide poisoning are generally treated with 100% oxygen via a non-rebreathing mask. However, hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated to accelerate the elimination of COHb if any of the following are present: COHb > 25% (or > 15% in a pregnant woman), neurological manifestations (e.g., confusion, loss of consciousness, seizures, focal neurological deficits), ECG changes or clinical features of acute myocardial ischemia (e.g., chest pain), and severe acidosis (pH < 7.1).

Sumatriptan is an abortive treatment for migraine. Although migraines present with headache and nausea, as in this patient, other features, such as visual auras and photophobia, usually accompany acute attacks. Migraines are also not typically associated with confusion, memory loss, and an unsteady gait. Lastly, it would be very unusual for a patient to start developing migraines at 63 years of age.

Intravenous nitroprusside is indicated for decreasing blood pressure in patients with a hypertensive emergency, which may result in acute deterioration with headache, nausea, and confusion. However, an acute deterioration due to hypertension is usually seen in patients when blood pressure is > 180/120 mm Hg and/or if intracranial hemorrhage occurs. This patient has a normal blood pressure and no neurological deficits or signs of meningism to suggest an intracranial hemorrhage.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of diarrhea, flatulence, and fatigue. She reports having 3–5 episodes of loose stools daily that have an oily appearance. The symptoms are worse after eating. She also complains of an itchy rash on her elbows and knees. A photograph of the rash is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of diarrhea, flatulence, and fatigue. She reports having 3–5 episodes of loose stools daily that have an oily appearance. The symptoms are worse after eating. She also complains of an itchy rash on her elbows and knees. A photograph of the rash is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This woman's rash is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis and her symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., fatty diarrhea, flatulence, fatigue) are suggestive of celiac disease.
learning_objective: Recognize celiac disease, and recall its associated HLA serotype.

answers.explanation_why: Malabsorptive conditions that cause macrocytic, hypochromic anemia due to vitamin B_12 and/or folate deficiency include tropical sprue, atrophic gastritis, and chronic pancreatitis. Celiac disease causes malabsorption of iron in the duodenum and may result in a microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

Decreased fecal elastase levels are seen in patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., from chronic pancreatitis). Although this condition can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. In addition, patients with chronic pancreatitis typically have epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back and improves upon leaning forward (though in the later stages of chronic pancreatitis, patients may not have any pain).

Biopsy results that show PAS-positive intestinal macrophages confirm a diagnosis of Whipple disease. Although this condition can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. In addition, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of Whipple disease, such as sacroiliitis, polyserositis, and/or lymphadenopathy.

HLA-DQ2 is a cell surface receptor of antigen-presenting cells associated with 90–95% of cases of celiac disease. Expression of HLA-DQ2 is thought to predispose patients to celiac disease due to increased binding of gluten peptides to this HLA subtype, triggering a T-cell mediated autoimmune reaction and inflammation of the intestinal epithelium. Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease and is caused by deposition of IgA and complement C3 in dermal papillae of the dermis.

images.title: Celiac disease etiopathogenesis
images.description: The ingestion of gliadin, a component of gluten, leads to an immune response in the intestinal epithelium in individuals with celiac disease. Gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and then ingested by antigen-presenting cells (APC), which activate T cells via MHC II receptors. The activated T cell then activates plasma cells to release anti-tTG, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin antibodies (which all function as diagnostic markers of celiac disease). T cells also differentiate into TH1 cells, which activate cytoplasmic fibroblasts to release matrix proteases. This leads to the destruction of the intestinal architecture with villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and the loss of the brush border.

answers.explanation_why: Elevation in exhaled hydrogen concentration when performing a lactose or hydrogen breath test is seen in patients with lactose malabsorption or small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. Although both of these conditions can manifest with diarrhea and flatulence, neither is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

Elevation in urine tryptophan levels is seen in patients with Hartnup disease. This condition can cause diarrhea and a skin rash (due to niacin deficiency); however, the typical rash involves the neck (Casal necklace) and manifests with hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas. In addition, patients with Hartnup disease often develop features of dementia and glossitis, which this patient does not have.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped papulovesicular eruptions with excoriations and surrounding erythema are visible on the lower arms and elbows (A) and knees (B).These findings, in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

question_text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of painful, firm, dark bumps on his neck and jawline. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His brother had a similar rash that improved with topical erythromycin therapy. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of painful, firm, dark bumps on his neck and jawline. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His brother had a similar rash that improved with topical erythromycin therapy. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
hint: The image shows multiple small, dark, firm papules and some pustules on a man's shaved neck, which are manifestations of pseudofolliculitis barbae.
learning_objective: Recognize pseudofolliculitis barbae, and recall its pathogenesis.

answers.content: Trichophyton infection of the superficial hair follicle
answers.explanation_why: Trichophyton (dermatophyte) infection of the superficial hair follicle of the beard area causes tinea barbae, which can manifest with pustules. However, this condition more typically causes an inflamed region with an enlarging, raised, erythematous ring with a clear center and elevated edges. There is often associated hair loss.

images.title: Tinea barbae
images.description: Localization: face of an older patient; right side above the mouthLesion: red, inflamed region with follicular papules above the mouth; additional papules on the chinAdditional symptoms: regional lymphadenitis, fever, reduced medical conditionDifferential diagnosis: bacterial infection, HSV infection

answers.content: Cutibacterium acnes colonization of the pilosebaceous unit
answers.explanation_why: Cutibacterium acnes colonization of the pilosebaceous unit causes acne vulgaris, which manifests primarily on the face with inflammatory papules, pustules, nodules, and comedones. This patient does not have comedones, and the distribution of lesions is atypical for acne vulgaris.

images.title: Acne vulgaris
images.description: Disseminated papules, pustules, and comedones on an erythematous base are visible on the seborrheic skin of the patient's forehead.These findings are consistent with moderate acne vulgaris.

answers.content: Follicular obstruction with subsequent duct rupture
answers.explanation_why: Follicular obstruction with subsequent duct rupture is characteristic of hidradenitis suppurativa. This condition most often affects the intertriginous areas (e.g., axillary, groin, perineal regions) and is associated with fistula formation, scarring, and foul odor, which are not seen in this case.

answers.content: Interfollicular penetration of the skin by distal end of hair
answers.explanation_why: Pseudofolliculitis barbae primarily affects African American men or men with curly hair and is characterized by an inflammatory reaction to ingrown hairs (e.g., after shaving). The hair either enters the interfollicular epidermis after exiting the follicular orifice (extrafollicular penetration) or penetrates the dermis before exiting the follicular orifice (transfollicular penetration). The resulting inflammatory reaction against the hair leads to the characteristic finding of painful papules distributed along the areas of facial hair growth. Management of pseudofolliculitis barbae includes cessation of shaving and adjunctive topical therapies (e.g., topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and antimicrobial therapy to treat secondary infection).

answers.content: Bacterial infection of the superficial or deep hair follicle
answers.explanation_why: Bacterial folliculitis is characterized predominantly by pustules and erythematous papules on hair-growing areas of the skin, not by the firm, dark papules as seen in this case.

images.title: Pseudofolliculitis barbae
images.description: Multiple small, hyperpigmented papules are visible in the area of hair growth on the neck.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a 3-month history of insomnia, odynophagia, and irritability. He works in a metal refinery. He appears distracted and irritable. Oral examination shows inflammation of the gums and buccal mucosa with excessive salivation. Neurological examination shows a broad-based gait and an intention tremor in both hands. After treatment with dimercaprol is begun, his symptoms slowly improve. This patient was most likely exposed to which of the following?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a 3-month history of insomnia, odynophagia, and irritability. He works in a metal refinery. He appears distracted and irritable. Oral examination shows inflammation of the gums and buccal mucosa with excessive salivation. Neurological examination shows a broad-based gait and an intention tremor in both hands. After treatment with dimercaprol is begun, his symptoms slowly improve. This patient was most likely exposed to which of the following?
hint: Dimercaprol is a thiol-based chelating agent used to treat metal toxicity.
learning_objective: Recognize mercury poisoning, and recall its treatment.

answers.explanation_why:
Mercury poisoning is the most likely explanation for this patient's presentation. Chronic mercury toxicity manifests with neuropsychiatric symptoms including anxiety, erethism mercurialis (abnormal irritability), ataxia, and tremor. Various degrees of polyneuropathy may also be observed. Another common sign is gingival and/or buccal inflammation with a characteristic blue‑violet discoloration. This patient's history of working in a metal refinery further supports this diagnosis. Finally, treatment includes administering dimercaprol, a chelating agent used to reduce serum mercury levels. The chelating agents 2,3 dimercaptopropane-1-sulfonate (DMPS) and dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) can also be used to lower mercury levels.

Lead poisoning would manifest with symptoms very similar to the ones in this case, including neuropsychiatric disturbances and anorexia. Dimercaprol is also the first-line treatment. However, this patient's prominent excess salivation, odynophagia, and gingival inflammation would not be expected in cases of lead poisoning.

Cyanide intoxication manifests acutely as confusion, vertigo, headache, nausea, and vomiting, which can progress to seizures and coma in severe cases. Affected patients are initially hypertensive and tachycardic but then develop hypotension and bradycardia as peripheral oxygen delivery deteriorates. Chronic toxicity most often causes non-specific symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, chest pain, and headache. Neither acute nor chronic exposure cause gingivobuccal inflammation, tremor, or ataxia. Finally, cyanide toxicity is usually treated with a combination of sodium thiosulfate and hydroxocobalamin or a combination of amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulfate, but not with dimercaprol.

Arsenic toxicity can occur after an acute exposure or following years of chronic exposure. In either case, the most prominent feature of toxicity is symmetrical peripheral neuropathy that can involve motor and sensory nerves. Chronic exposure will often cause characteristic white lines to appear in the fingernails; acute poisoning typically manifests with garlic-scented breath, seizures, and coma. Although dimercaprol is indicated in cases of arsenic poisoning, this patient's presentation is not consistent with acute or chronic arsenic poisoning.

Iron toxicity is most commonly seen in children, usually due to accidental ingestion of iron tablets. Acute iron toxicity typically manifests with hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, anion gap metabolic acidosis, respiratory depression, and altered consciousness, none of which this patient has. Chronic iron toxicity may cause renal and/or liver failure. Finally, iron toxicity is managed with deferoxamine, not dimercaprol.

Acute copper toxicity usually manifests with vomiting, diarrhea, melena, and abdominal pain. More severe or continued exposure may result in hemolytic anemia along with renal and/or hepatic failure. This patient's symptoms include neuropsychiatric components and gingivobuccal inflammation, neither of which are expected in copper toxicity. Furthermore, penicillamine is the first-line treatment for copper toxicity; dimercaprol is used less frequently.

question_text: A 35-year-old soldier is rescued from a helicopter crash in the Arctic Circle and brought back to a treatment facility at a nearby military base. On arrival, the patient's wet clothes are removed. He appears pale and is not shivering. He is unresponsive to verbal and painful stimuli. His temperature is 27.4°C (81.3°F), pulse is 30/min and irregular, respirations are 7/min, and blood pressure is 83/52 mm Hg. Examination shows fixed, dilated pupils and diffuse rigidity. The fingers and toes are white in color and hard to the touch. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. In addition to emergent intubation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old soldier is rescued from a helicopter crash in the Arctic Circle and brought back to a treatment facility at a nearby military base. On arrival, the patient's wet clothes are removed. He appears pale and is not shivering. He is unresponsive to verbal and painful stimuli. His temperature is 27.4°C (81.3°F), pulse is 30/min and irregular, respirations are 7/min, and blood pressure is 83/52 mm Hg. Examination shows fixed, dilated pupils and diffuse rigidity. The fingers and toes are white in color and hard to the touch. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. In addition to emergent intubation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's pallor, hypotension, fixed pupils, arrhythmia, and core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F) indicate a diagnosis of severe hypothermia.
learning_objective: Recognize severe hypothermia, and choose the most appropriate rewarming technique.

answers.content: Increasing the temperature of the room
answers.explanation_why: Increasing the temperature of the room is a passive external rewarming technique used in the management of patients with mild hypothermia, which is defined by a core body temperature of 32–35°C (90–95°F) and has manifestations that include tachycardia, tachypnea, confusion, amnesia, dysarthria, impaired judgment, and ataxia. Other passive external rewarming techniques include removing wet clothing and covering with blankets. Passive external warming will not adequately treat this patient, who has severe hypothermia.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of tissue plasminogen activator
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of tissue plasminogen activator is used to treat patients with severe frostbite who are at high risk for amputation. Though this patient has manifestations of frostbite (e.g., pale and hard fingers and toes) that should be further evaluated and treated, these actions are not the most appropriate next steps in management.

Intravenous administration of diltiazem can be used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. However, rate control is not emergently needed to treat this patient's arrhythmia, which will likely resolve upon treatment of his underlying severe hypothermia.

answers.content: Application of heating pads to the extremities
answers.explanation_why: Application of heating pads to the extremities is an active external rewarming technique used in the management of patients with moderate hypothermia, which is defined by a core body temperature of 28–32°C (82–90°F) and has manifestations that include CNS depression, hypoventilation, hyporeflexia, oliguria, bradycardia, and arrhythmias. Other active external rewarming techniques include the application of warm blankets and warm air. Active external warming will not adequately treat this patient, who has severe hypothermia.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of warmed normal saline
answers.explanation_why: Following emergent resuscitation, active internal rewarming is the most appropriate treatment for patients with severe hypothermia. Active internal rewarming techniques include intravenous administration of a warmed crystalloid solution, warmed irrigation of the peritoneum, and extracorporeal blood rewarming.
Electrical cardioversion is not emergently needed to treat this patient's arrhythmia, which will likely resolve upon treatment of his underlying severe hypothermia.
