question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand. Two days ago, she was camping outdoors in Texas with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, she saw a wound on her hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours she noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand. Two days ago, she was camping outdoors in Texas with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, she saw a wound on her hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours she noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
hint: This animal is most easily identified by the violin-shaped marking on its back.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of a brown recluse spider bite, and recall its geographic distribution.

answers.explanation_why: Bald-faced hornets are found throughout North America, especially in the southern United States, including the state of Texas. Although their sting typically causes signs of local inflammation (erythema, induration), bluish-black skin discoloration and skin necrosis are not expected.

Diamondback rattlesnakes are found throughout the southwestern United States, including the state of Texas. Their bite is very painful and their venom contains hemotoxic, cytotoxic, and myotoxic proteins, which lead to localized progressive edema, ecchymoses, internal bleeding, muscle damage, and necrosis. More severe effects include disseminated intravascular coagulation, shock, and death.

Brown recluse spiders are endemic to some regions of the southern (e.g., Texas), southeastern, and midwestern United States. They produce venom composed of various enzymes, some of which cause local destruction of tissue integrity, leading to the breakdown of skin, adipose tissue, vasculature, and eventual tissue death. Bites are initially painless but form into an erythematous, painful blister over the course of several hours. Progressive tissue death and bluish-black skin discoloration are seen in the first 24 hours, followed by tissue necrosis and eschar formation by the end of the first week. Systemic findings, although uncommon, include fever, malaise, nausea, and vomiting. Life-threatening complications are extremely rare. Treatment consists of cleansing the wound, analgesics for pain, and tetanus prophylaxis. Antimicrobials are indicated if the wound becomes infected. In severe necrotic lesions, tissue debridement may be necessary.

images.title: Brown recluse spider
images.description: The violin-shaped marking on the cephalothorax is typical of the brown recluse spider (L. reclusa), a species of Loxosceles endemic to the southeastern and midwestern United States. These spiders produce venom composed of various enzymes, some of which cause local destruction of tissue integrity, leading to the breakdown of skin, adipose tissue, vasculature, and, ultimately, necrosis. Bites are initially painless but form into an erythematous, painful blister over the course of several hours. Progressive tissue death and bluish-black skin discoloration of the skin are seen within the first 24 hours, followed by tissue necrosis and eschar formation by the end of the first week. Systemic findings, although uncommon, include fever, malaise, nausea, and vomiting. Life-threatening complications are extremely rare.

answers.explanation_why: Striped bark scorpions are endemic to the state of Texas. Their sting is typically painful and causes localized swelling at the sting site. Neurotoxins produced in the venom may cause paresthesia and muscle spasms. In severe cases, cranial nerve dysfunction, neuromuscular dysfunction, and/or hypersensitivity reactions may occur. A painless erythematous lesion that leads to progressive tissue destruction characterized by bluish-black discoloration and skin necrosis, as seen in this patient, would not be expected.

Deer ticks, which are most commonly found in the northeastern United States, are vectors for Lyme disease. Although early manifestations of Lyme disease may include a painless red rash (erythema migrans) and flu-like symptoms such as the low-grade fever seen in this patient, progressive tissue destruction characterized by bluish-black discoloration and skin necrosis would not be expected.

Black widow spiders are endemic to the state of Texas. Their bite typically begins as a painful erythematous macule, which progresses to form a “target lesion” with a pale center surrounded by erythema. Their venom causes exocytosis of neurotransmitters from presynaptic nerve terminals, which leads to muscle pain and spasms, severe abdominal pain with rigidity, paresthesias, and autonomic dysfunction, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, progressive tissue destruction characterized by bluish-black discoloration and skin necrosis would not be expected.

question_text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm for 1 day. The rash started as small papules, then progressed into blisters with oozing. He has had atopic dermatitis since the age of 6 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. Avoidance of contact with which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm for 1 day. The rash started as small papules, then progressed into blisters with oozing. He has had atopic dermatitis since the age of 6 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. Avoidance of contact with which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's symptoms are likely the result of a T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.
learning_objective: Recognize allergic contact dermatitis, and choose the appropriate allergen avoidance to prevent symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Cat dander is a potential trigger for an acute flare of atopic dermatitis (AD), which manifests with dry skin and intense pruritus. Patients with AD may develop excoriations due to itching that would appear as linear skin lesions. However, lesions in AD are not associated with papules and oozing vesicles. Moreover, AD is most likely to affect the flexural creases (e.g., antecubital fossa, popliteal fossa) instead of the forearm.

images.title: Cat scratch disease
images.description: A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

answers.explanation_why: The erythematous, pruritic, and papular rash on this patient's forearm could raise concern for papular urticaria. Papular urticaria is the result of a type I hypersensitivity reaction to insect bites or stings. However, it is not usually associated with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles. More commonly, bee stings cause a classical urticarial reaction (well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques), which is not seen here. Furthermore, bee stings are typically associated with pain and swelling at the affected site, which this patient does not report.

images.title: Urticaria
images.description: Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's pruritic and erythematous papular rash with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles should raise suspicion for allergic contact dermatitis (ACD), a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The characteristic skin lesions commonly appear 12–48 hours after exposure to the allergen in individuals that have previously been sensitized. Triggers of ACD include certain plants (i.e., poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac, which cause urushiol-induced dermatitis), nickel, rubber/latex, cosmetics, and certain topical medications. Management consists of avoidance of triggers, topical corticosteroids and wet dressings for mild to moderate cases, and systemic corticosteroids for severe cases (e.g., widespread rash, ACD involving the face).

The erythematous, pruritic papules and vesicles on this patient's forearm could be a result of a polymorphous light eruption (“sun allergy”). This photodermatosis is thought to be caused by a T cell-mediated type IV hypersensitivity response to high-intensity UV exposure after a period of little exposure (e.g., first prolonged sunlight exposure in spring or early summer). However, the rash associated with polymorphous light eruption is typically distributed in a bilateral, symmetric manner on several sun-exposed skin areas. This patient's rash is limited to his right arm, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Polymorphous light eruption
images.description: Erythematous papules and lesions with irregular borders are visible on the cheeks and forehead.

answers.explanation_why: The erythematous, pruritic papules and vesicles on this patient's forearm could be a form of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), which can be caused by a T cell-mediated immunological response to gluten and is associated with celiac disease. However, DH is associated with grouped vesicles (herpetiform appearance) rather than the linear vesicles seen here. Moreover, DH is usually bilateral and symmetrical in distribution, as opposed to this patient's unilateral rash. Finally, this patient has no history of celiac disease and does not report associated symptoms such as gastrointestinal complaints or signs of malabsorption.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

images.title: Urushiol-induced contact dermatitis
images.description: An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

question_text: One week after admission to the hospital for burns sustained in a building fire, a 24-year-old man undergoes evaluation for the feasibility of skin grafting. Physical examination shows third-degree burns on his entire torso, left arm, and head. Urine and blood cultures grow no organisms. A chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following changes are most likely to be seen in this patient at this time?
content_preview: One week after admission to the hospital for burns sustained in a building fire, a 24-year-old man undergoes evaluation for the feasibility of skin grafting. Physical examination shows third-degree burns on his entire torso, left arm, and head. Urine and blood cultures grow no organisms. A chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following changes are most likely to be seen in this patient at this time?
hint: This change would also be seen in patients with hyperthyroidism.
learning_objective: Recall the metabolic changes following severe burns, and recall the phases of postburn hypermetabolic response.

answers.explanation_why:
Increased resting energy expenditure is a typical finding in patients one week after severe thermal injury. Severe burns, as seen in this patient, lead to a hypermetabolic state, which provides energy to the cells involved in wound healing and counters the significant heat and water loss that results from the loss of insulating cutaneous tissue. This postburn hypermetabolic response is characterized by two distinct phases. During the first phase (called the “Ebb phase,” up to 48 hours postburn), cardiac output and metabolism are decreased. The second phase (called the “flow phase”) is characterized by an increase in stress-induced hormones (e.g., catecholamines, glucocorticoids) and inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α), which lead to a gradual increase in metabolism, cardiac output, and body temperature until reaching a plateau (around one week postburn). Consequences of the hypermetabolic response include hyperglycemia, peripheral insulin resistance, increased muscle protein degradation, increased lipolysis, and significant weight loss.

Postburn hypermetabolism can last up to 2–3 years and is associated with poor long-term results (e.g., immune dysfunction and infections, delayed wound healing). Therapeutic strategies to alter this response include early excision of necrotic tissue and skin grafting, thermoregulation, early enteral feeding with a high-carbohydrate, high-protein diet, glycemic control, beta blockers, anabolic steroids, pain management, and supportive psychotherapy.

Nitrogen balance represents the difference between nitrogen intake and nitrogen loss and depends on the level of intake and breakdown of amino acids in proteins. In patients one week after severe thermal injury, nitrogen balance is typically decreased, not increased, which is a result of increased proteolysis induced by inflammatory cytokines and stress hormones.

Peripheral lipolysis in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, secondary to the release of catecholamines and other stress hormones that promote lipid degradation.

Corticosteroid secretion in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, as extensive burns lead to a hypermetabolic response that induces the secretion of stress hormones.
Cardiac output in patients one week after severe thermal injury is typically increased, not decreased, most likely due to the increased release of stress hormones, which increase cardiac output.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman vacationing in Hawaii is brought to a lifeguard by her sister after being stung by a jellyfish at the beach. She had been walking in the water along the shore when she suddenly developed sharp pain along her right shin, which is now burning and throbbing. Her sister noticed that red lesions tracking up the leg appeared a few minutes after the patient exited the waters. Since then, the patient has also developed a mild headache, waves of nausea, and sweating. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time, but is confused about why her leg hurts and how they reached the lifeguard. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows linear, cross-hatched, ladder-like erythematous lesions along her right calf. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management by the lifeguard?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman vacationing in Hawaii is brought to a lifeguard by her sister after being stung by a jellyfish at the beach. She had been walking in the water along the shore when she suddenly developed sharp pain along her right shin, which is now burning and throbbing. Her sister noticed that red lesions tracking up the leg appeared a few minutes after the patient exited the waters. Since then, the patient has also developed a mild headache, waves of nausea, and sweating. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time, but is confused about why her leg hurts and how they reached the lifeguard. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows linear, cross-hatched, ladder-like erythematous lesions along her right calf. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management by the lifeguard?
hint: A jellyfish sting in Hawaii that manifests with a characteristic “frosted ladder” appearance is consistent with a sting from an Indo-Pacific box jellyfish (e.g., Chironex fleckeri). Jellyfish have tentacles with specialized capsules (nematocysts) that attach to the patient's skin and release venom. If systemic envenomation cannot be prevented, a box jellyfish sting can result in rapid-onset cardiac arrest.
learning_objective: Recognize a jellyfish sting, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Applying topical vinegar for 30 seconds reduces venom discharge from the nematocysts of Australian and Indo-Pacific box jellyfish. Next, any remaining attached tentacles should be carefully pulled off the patient (use gloves if available). Although the rescuer may sustain a minor sting, the latter does not pose a risk to the rescuer; after the removal, the rescuer must rinse the hands with seawater. After topical vinegar application and tentacle removal, topical cold therapy should be applied to alleviate local pain and the patient's transport to the emergency department for observation and definitive care should be arranged. For patients with life-threatening manifestations such as respiratory or cardiac arrest, an antivenom is available.
answers.explanation_but: The initial approach differs depending on the jellyfish species. Stings by jellyfish outside Australia and the Indo-Pacific region (e.g., Portuguese Physalia species) should not be treated with vinegar as this may stimulate venom discharge or worsen local symptoms. Instead, the tentacles should be directly removed and the sting location must be rinsed with seawater. Next, the affected body part must be immersed in hot water to alleviate local pain. Some research recommends topical application of a 50% baking soda mixture to stings from certain Atlantic jellyfish species (e.g., Cyanea capillata).

images.title: Box jellyfish sting
images.description: Linear erythematous lesions in a cross-hatched, so-called "frosted-ladder" pattern are visible.This is the characteristic appearance of a box jellyfish sting.

answers.content: Scratch off tentacles and place tourniquet
answers.explanation_why: Scratching off the tentacles of the jellyfish is not indicated as the pressure applied would further promote nematocyst venom release. Placing a tourniquet is also not effective in preventing venom release or spread.

Administering oral antihistamines in combination with topical corticosteroids may be helpful to treat a delayed hypersensitivity reaction in response to a jellyfish sting. However, there is no proven benefit in the acute setting.

Applying topical alcohol to jellyfish stings is generally deemed ineffective and may, in fact, exacerbate local symptoms. Other substances that are often proposed as local remedies but should also be avoided include denatured alcohol (methylated spirits), urine, papain meat tenderizer, ammonia, and aluminum sulfate solutions.
Rinsing the lesion with freshwater is not recommended as it stimulates venom release from nematocysts.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV_1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
hint: This patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, digital clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, and restrictive pattern of lung disease on spirometry (normal to increased FEV_1:FVC ratio, decreased VC) raises concern for interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, which indicate carbon-laden macrophages, and imaging findings are characteristic of exposure to a noxious agent in this field of work.
learning_objective: Recognize black lung disease, and recall the risk factor for this pneumoconiosis.

answers.explanation_why: Construction workers (e.g., plumbing, roofing, insulation), firefighters wearing heat-resistant clothing, and shipbuilders with cumulative exposure to asbestos are at risk for asbestosis. While patients with asbestosis present with dyspnea and chronic cough, chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages. Carbon-laden macrophages are not an expected biopsy finding in asbestosis.

Workers exposed to silica dust (e.g., in sandblasting, mining, casting metals) are at risk for silicosis, which usually manifests with a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. Chest x-ray findings in silicosis also typically appear on the upper lobes more than the lower lobes with hilar eggshell calcifications and nodular opacities. However, lung biopsy findings typically show silicotic nodules, which are composed of collagen fibers surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes, and, possibly, intra- or extracellular birefringent silica particles. Carbon-laden macrophages are not a common biopsy finding in silicosis.

Workers in uranium processing (especially mining) can be exposed to radon gas, a radioactive byproduct of uranium decay, which increases the risk of lung cancer. Chest x-ray findings in lung cancer typically show a solitary nodule, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, uranium workers can be exposed to dusts, including silica, which increases the risk for silicosis. In this condition, chest x-ray characteristically shows interstitial nodular opacities in the upper lobes similar to the findings in this patient. However, lung biopsy in silicosis typically shows silicotic nodules, which do not include carbon-laden macrophages.

Workers in aerospace manufacturing are often exposed to beryllium alloys, which can cause berylliosis following high-grade exposure. Although berylliosis can manifest with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, lung biopsy typically reveals noncaseating granulomas similar to those seen in sarcoidosis rather than carbon-laden macrophages. Additionally, while opacities are also typically seen more in the upper lobes than the lower lobes of the lung, chest x-ray would reveal more of a reticular interstitial pattern.

Farmers are chronically exposed to organic dust (e.g., from molds, animal proteins) and are at risk for chronic hypersensitivity pneumonia, which is characterized by slowly progressive dyspnea, bilateral crackles, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. However, chest x-ray typically shows ground-glass opacities with honeycombing (fibrotic changes), and lung biopsy is likely to reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells rather than carbon-laden macrophages.

Coal miners are at increased risk of coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also called black lung disease, a more severe form of anthracosis caused by chronic occupational exposure to large amounts of carbon dust. Patients with coal workers' pneumoconiosis present with symptoms of chronic bronchitis, which can progress to severe dyspnea indicating massive pulmonary fibrosis. Inhaled carbon particles accumulate in alveolar macrophages and induce inflammation and fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. Chest x-ray can reveal small, nodular, potentially coalescing opacities in the upper lung lobes. Finally, lung biopsy characteristically shows deposition of dark pigment in macrophages, interstitial tissue, and hilar lymph nodes.

Caplan syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis, including coal workers' pneumoconiosis, that manifests with rheumatoid arthritis. Although this patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, he does not have Caplan syndrome. If he were to develop this complication, he would likely present with concurrent symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, more rapidly progressive shortness of breath, chest x-ray findings of more peripheral and/or larger nodules, and biopsy findings similar to those seen in rheumatoid nodules (i.e., central fibrinoid necrosis with histiocytes and surrounding epithelial cells).

images.title: Anthracotic pigment in lung in coal worker's pneumoconiosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain, low magnification)Accumulations of carbon particles (anthracotic pigment) can be seen in the lung tissue. Some of the pigment can be found in pigment-laden macrophages. Also, collagenous fibrosis is predominant throughout the lung tissue.This appearance is diagnostic of pneumoconiosis (e.g., coal workers' pneumoconiosis).

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of right forearm pain at the site of a honeybee sting. She was stung a few hours ago at tennis practice when she inadvertently picked up a ball with a honeybee on it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has no allergies, takes no medications, and her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a stinger with the attached venom sac in her right forearm. There is an area of erythema and swelling of approximately 1 cm in diameter at the sting site that is tender to palpation. The physician scrapes off the stinger with a piece of gauze, washes the sting site with soap and water, and applies a cold compress. In addition to prescribing analgesics and asking the patient to keep the right forearm elevated, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of right forearm pain at the site of a honeybee sting. She was stung a few hours ago at tennis practice when she inadvertently picked up a ball with a honeybee on it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has no allergies, takes no medications, and her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a stinger with the attached venom sac in her right forearm. There is an area of erythema and swelling of approximately 1 cm in diameter at the sting site that is tender to palpation. The physician scrapes off the stinger with a piece of gauze, washes the sting site with soap and water, and applies a cold compress. In addition to prescribing analgesics and asking the patient to keep the right forearm elevated, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with a small area (< 5 cm in diameter) of erythema and swelling around a Hymenoptera sting site, indicating an uncomplicated local reaction.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for an uncomplicated local reaction to a Hymenoptera sting.

answers.explanation_why: Allergic skin testing is usually needed to confirm the diagnosis of Hymenoptera venom allergy in patients with a history of a systemic allergic reaction following a Hymenoptera sting. In patients with local skin reactions, there is no indication for allergic skin testing because the probability of developing a systemic life-threatening reaction is low. Moreover, in patients with no history of a systemic allergic reaction, a positive skin test is neither diagnostic nor predicts the risk of developing a systemic reaction following a sting, since more than a quarter of the general population has venom-specific IgE antibodies but only a minority actually reports systemic reactions.

Oral prednisone is used in the treatment of large local reactions (LLR) to Hymenoptera stings, which manifest with an area of erythema and painful swelling greater than approx. 10 cm in diameter. While small local reactions can gradually increase and develop into an LLR within two days following a sting, this patient currently has a small local reaction; oral prednisone is not necessary at this time.

answers.content: No further management is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: Uncomplicated local reactions to a Hymenoptera sting only require symptomatic treatment to limit the inflammatory reaction and reduce the pain. The inflammatory reaction to a sting is induced by the venom released from the venom sac of Hymenoptera's stinging apparatus. Since the venom is expelled during the first few minutes after a sting, immediate stinger removal (only applied to Hymenoptera species that lose their stingers after stinging, like honeybees) might limit venom release. Sting removal can be done by scraping off the stinger with a piece of gauze or fingernail but not with tweezers, because of the risk of further squeezing the venom sac. Following removal, the site should be washed with soap and water, cold compresses should be applied, and NSAIDs can be used for pain relief. If present, pruritus can be treated with oral antihistamines or topical steroids. In patients with large local reactions (> 10 cm in diameter), oral steroids can be used.

Observation in a hospital setting is indicated to monitor patients who were previously treated for sting-induced anaphylaxis or are at risk for developing an anaphylactic reaction. This patient, however, only has a localized skin reaction, which does not require observation in a hospital setting.

Epinephrine is used in the treatment of anaphylaxis, which can be triggered by Hymenoptera stings. This patient, however, does not have typical findings of anaphylaxis, such as urticaria, angioedema, chest tightness, dyspnea, or hypotension. Epinephrine can also be administered following a sting in patients with a history of sting-induced anaphylaxis, which is not the case here. Patients with sting-induced anaphylaxis should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector prior to discharge and instructed on how and when to use it.

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of a red, itchy rash on his left hand. He has never had a similar rash before. He does not have any known allergies. Medical history is remarkable for exercise-induced asthma controlled with a metered-dose albuterol inhaler. He works as a hairdresser and says, “My boss told me yesterday to stop working because the customers are scared it might be contagious.” He lives with a roommate who has not had any similar skin symptoms. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms regularly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows macular erythema, xerosis, and fine, white scaling on the dorsum of the left hand. There are linear fissures in several of the flexural creases of the interphalangeal joints. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of a red, itchy rash on his left hand. He has never had a similar rash before. He does not have any known allergies. Medical history is remarkable for exercise-induced asthma controlled with a metered-dose albuterol inhaler. He works as a hairdresser and says, “My boss told me yesterday to stop working because the customers are scared it might be contagious.” He lives with a roommate who has not had any similar skin symptoms. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms regularly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows macular erythema, xerosis, and fine, white scaling on the dorsum of the left hand. There are linear fissures in several of the flexural creases of the interphalangeal joints. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's rash is likely exacerbated by occupational exposures, including frequent “wet work.”
learning_objective: Recognize irritant contact dermatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Atopic dermatitis (AD) can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous, scaly rash and the hands can be affected in adults with AD. However, AD is commonly bilateral rather than unilateral, and other skin flexures (e.g., knee flexures) are more commonly affected than the hands. Moreover, AD manifestations usually start early in life, and this patient has never had similar features before.

images.title: Atopic dermatitis
images.description: Ill-defined, erythematous macules with excoriations are seen on the flexural surface of the knee.This finding is characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Psoriasis can manifest with pruritic, erythematous, scaly skin lesions. However, psoriatic lesions are typically hyperkeratotic plaques rather than erythematous macules. Moreover, psoriasis usually manifests with symmetrically distributed lesions, with a predilection for extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows, knees), the scalp, and the lower back; it is highly unlikely that a single hand would be affected.

images.title: Plaque psoriasis
images.description: Multiple sharply demarcated erythematosquamous plaques with coarse, silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor sides of the lower arms and elbows.

answers.explanation_why: Seborrheic dermatitis can manifest with a pruritic, scaly, erythematous rash. However, seborrheic dermatitis does not typically affect the hands. The most commonly affected areas in seborrheic dermatitis are those of high sebaceous activity (e.g., eyebrows, nasolabial folds, scalp, upper chest), none of which are affected in this patient.

images.title: Seborrheic dermatitis
images.description: Chest of a male patientErythema with fine scaling is visible between and underneath the breasts.These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

answers.explanation_why:
Irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) is the most common form of contact dermatitis. Irritants can be chemical (e.g., water, detergents, solvents) and/or physical (e.g., wood, dust, fiberglass); this patient's occupation (hairdressing) increases his risk of developing ICD due to frequent exposure to chemical irritants (e.g., water, shampoos, permanent wave solutions). The manifestations of ICD are typically limited to the area of exposure. This patient's mild pruritus, erythema, scaling, xerosis, and fissuring are characteristic of chronic ICD, which is more common with exposure to weak irritants (e.g., water, soaps, shampoos). Treatment includes avoidance of irritants, moisturizers to restore the epidermal skin barrier, and symptomatic treatment with topical corticosteroids.

ICD is caused by a direct cytotoxic effect and is not immune-mediated, as opposed to allergic contact dermatitis, which is a T-cell mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction. To differentiate ICD from allergic contact dermatitis, a patch test for relevant allergens should be performed.

Scabies manifests with erythematous, pruritic skin lesions and typically affects the hands, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, unilateral lesions on the dorsum of the hand are not typical. Moreover, excoriated papules and serpiginous erythema due to burrows on interdigital folds, medial aspects of fingers, and flexor surface of wrists would be expected. Finally, scabies is contagious, and close contacts (e.g., roommates) are commonly affected.

images.title: Scabies skin lesions
images.description: Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

question_text: A 20-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Navy is brought to a military hospital because of a 1-hour history of back pain, inability to urinate, progressive leg weakness, and a burning and prickling sensation in the lower limbs. He is a military diver in training. Four hours before the onset of symptoms, he had taken part in a 3-hour scuba diving exercise to a depth of 30 m (98.4 ft). The dive was uneventful until the patient encountered problems with mask clearing, which led to a rapid ascent. About 1 hour after surfacing, the patient began to feel exceptionally tired and started having headaches. He appears somnolent. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mottling, reticular skin rash. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left leg and 4/5 in the right leg. Sensation to vibration and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 20-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Navy is brought to a military hospital because of a 1-hour history of back pain, inability to urinate, progressive leg weakness, and a burning and prickling sensation in the lower limbs. He is a military diver in training. Four hours before the onset of symptoms, he had taken part in a 3-hour scuba diving exercise to a depth of 30 m (98.4 ft). The dive was uneventful until the patient encountered problems with mask clearing, which led to a rapid ascent. About 1 hour after surfacing, the patient began to feel exceptionally tired and started having headaches. He appears somnolent. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mottling, reticular skin rash. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left leg and 4/5 in the right leg. Sensation to vibration and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has decompression sickness (DCS), which typically occurs within 24 hours after scuba diving and can affect the spinal cord (e.g., back pain, paresis and paresthesias of the lower extremities, bladder dysfunction), brain (e.g., headache, altered mental status), and skin (e.g., cutis marmorata).
learning_objective: Recognize decompression sickness, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why:
In a patient with DCS, hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) is the most appropriate treatment and should be initiated as soon as possible. In a high-pressure environment (e.g., during scuba diving), a large amount of gas (primarily nitrogen) is dissolved in blood and tissue fluid. With a sudden subsequent decrease in pressure (e.g., during rapid ascent), air bubbles form because the gas is no longer dissolved (Henry's law) and they begin to expand (Boyle's law). These bubbles cause local tissue damage and are primarily responsible for the multisystem manifestations of DCS, which can also include chest pain, dyspnea, myalgia, arthralgia, pruritus, painful lymphadenopathy, and lymphedema. In severe cases, air embolization can also occur. In HBOT, the patient is placed in a high-pressure chamber to decrease the number and volume of any air bubbles that have already formed, and the chamber pressure is then decreased to atmospheric pressure at a slow rate to prevent the formation of new bubbles. While in the chamber, the patient receives 100% oxygen, which creates a gradient for the diffusion of nitrogen out of the body via the lungs.

Patients who do not fully respond to therapy may require multiple sessions until complete resolution or until there is no further improvement. If an HBOT facility is not readily available, the patient should receive 100% oxygen until the patient can be moved to such a facility. Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (for those with lower extremity paralysis) and adequate hydration are also recommended as adjunctive therapy in DCS.

Urgent lumbar decompression surgery is required to treat acute and severe spinal canal stenosis (e.g., due to trauma or disk herniation), which can similarly manifest with paresis, sensory deficits, and urinary incontinence. This patient has DCS, which requires a different treatment.

Thrombolytic therapy is used to treat thromboembolic stroke, which occurs acutely and, when affecting the anterior cerebral artery or anterior spinal artery, can manifest with some of the features seen here (e.g., paresis and paresthesias in a lower extremity, urinary incontinence). This patient with DCS and lower extremity paralysis requires thromboprophylaxis but not thrombolytic therapy.

In the Trendelenburg position, the outflow tracts of the right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) are at a lower level than the cavities of these ventricles. This position is used to prevent obstructive shock from large venous air emboli because it allows air to accumulate near the RV wall instead of blocking the RV outflow tract. The position can also decrease the risk of arterial air emboli reaching the cerebral circulation. Although patients with severe DCS can develop venous and arterial air emboli, cerebral edema due to localized tissue damage is a much more common complication of DCS. The Trendelenburg position increases cerebral perfusion and can worsen cerebral edema and is, therefore, no longer recommended for DCS.
Induced hypothermia (therapeutic hypothermia) is used following ischemic stroke and return of spontaneous circulation after cardiac arrest. It is not currently used to treat decompression sickness.
Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone), which reduce edema, are used to treat traumatic spinal cord injury. They are not currently recommended in the management of decompression sickness.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to a mountain base camp at 4000 m (13,100 ft) above sea level because he has had a 2-hour history of confusion, difficulties walking, and decreased responsiveness. He has been participating in a 5-day hiking trip in which the group has ascended 1500 m (4900 ft) from the base camp in 2 days. This morning, the third day of the trip, the patient was found in his tent unable to respond to simple questions and having wet himself. The night before, he reported headaches, dizziness, and nausea. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Neurological examination shows slurred speech and an ataxic gait. Kernig sign is absent. Further diagnostic studies cannot be performed due to limited medical equipment. The most appropriate initial step in management is the administration of which of the following?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to a mountain base camp at 4000 m (13,100 ft) above sea level because he has had a 2-hour history of confusion, difficulties walking, and decreased responsiveness. He has been participating in a 5-day hiking trip in which the group has ascended 1500 m (4900 ft) from the base camp in 2 days. This morning, the third day of the trip, the patient was found in his tent unable to respond to simple questions and having wet himself. The night before, he reported headaches, dizziness, and nausea. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Neurological examination shows slurred speech and an ataxic gait. Kernig sign is absent. Further diagnostic studies cannot be performed due to limited medical equipment. The most appropriate initial step in management is the administration of which of the following?
hint: Headaches, dizziness, and nausea while at an altitude over 2500 m (8000 ft) above sea level suggests acute mountain sickness (AMS). Altered consciousness, ataxia, and urinary incontinence are consistent with high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), a life-threatening complication of AMS.
learning_objective: Recognize high-altitude cerebral edema, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Nifedipine is used in the prevention and treatment of high altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE), a complication of AMS. While the severe hypoxemia in HAPE may lead to concomitant HACE, this patient shows no signs and symptoms of HAPE, such as cough, shortness of breath, cyanosis, tachypnea, tachycardia, and crackles or wheezing on pulmonary auscultation.

Haloperidol is used in the treatment of acute psychosis. While some of this patient's symptoms are also seen in acute psychosis (confusion, decreased responsiveness, slurred speech), loss of bladder control, headaches, dizziness, nausea, and ataxia are not expected. Moreover, typical symptoms of acute psychosis, such as hallucinations and delusions, are not present. Finally, this patient has no reported history of mental illness that could lead to acute psychosis (e.g., schizophrenia, bipolar disorder).
Mannitol is used in the treatment of cerebral edema. While this drug can be used to lower intracranial pressure in severe cases of HACE, it is not the initial treatment of choice.

Acetazolamide accelerates acclimatization to high altitude via multiple mechanisms (e.g., increased renal excretion of bicarbonate, increased ventilation and oxygenation) and is, therefore, used in the prevention and treatment of AMS. Acetazolamide is not, however, effective in the treatment of HACE.

Dexamethasone is a rescue medication for HACE that may significantly improve the patient's condition, and it should be administered as soon as this complication is suspected. However, dexamethasone does not replace the need for immediate descent to a lower altitude, which is the definitive treatment. Oxygen supplementation and portable hyperbaric therapy are further lifesaving measures if immediate evacuation is not possible. The most effective preventive measure for AMS and HACE is a slow ascent.

question_text: A 29-year-old man who lives in Utah comes to the emergency department 90 minutes after he received a snake bite on his right leg. He was cleaning out a shed in his backyard when he saw a snake between two beams of wood. When he tried to kill the snake with a shovel, it bit him in the lower leg. He says, “I don't really remember what it looked like other than that it was brown; I had a few beers before I started clearing out the shed, so it's all a bit fuzzy.” The bite site is painful. He is nauseous and says that he feels like he is about to vomit. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Physical examination shows two erythematous puncture wounds with serous drainage just above the right ankle. There is ecchymosis and swelling across the dorsum of the right foot and the lower leg up to the mid-shin. Active and passive range of motion of the right knee and ankle is limited by pain. Neurologic examination of the extremities shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man who lives in Utah comes to the emergency department 90 minutes after he received a snake bite on his right leg. He was cleaning out a shed in his backyard when he saw a snake between two beams of wood. When he tried to kill the snake with a shovel, it bit him in the lower leg. He says, “I don't really remember what it looked like other than that it was brown; I had a few beers before I started clearing out the shed, so it's all a bit fuzzy.” The bite site is painful. He is nauseous and says that he feels like he is about to vomit. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Physical examination shows two erythematous puncture wounds with serous drainage just above the right ankle. There is ecchymosis and swelling across the dorsum of the right foot and the lower leg up to the mid-shin. Active and passive range of motion of the right knee and ankle is limited by pain. Neurologic examination of the extremities shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The majority of snake bites in the US are by Crotalinae species, which are typically earth-toned. Treatment of snake envenomation is determined by the severity of clinical manifestations. This patient presents with systemic features, including nausea, tachycardia, tachypnea, and mild hypotension, which are consistent with envenomation of moderate severity.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a patient with moderate crotaline snake envenomation.

answers.explanation_why: Administration of antivenom is the most appropriate next step in management of a patient with moderate to severe envenomation by a crotaline snake. The clinical manifestations of envenomation are generally classified into three categories: local tissue effects (e.g., swelling and pain), systemic effects (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension, vomiting), and coagulopathic effects (e.g., hemorrhage, abnormal coagulation parameters). Severe cases can result in compartment syndrome, respiratory failure, life-threatening hypotension, and significant bleeding. Antivenom therapy can slow or halt the progression of toxicity and is most effective when administered within 6 hours of the snakebite. Crotalidae polyvalent immune fab and crotalidae immune f(ab')_2 are the antivenoms available in the United States. Patients who have received antivenom should be monitored for hypersensitivity (e.g., serum sickness, anaphylaxis). Additional management recommendations include pain control, local wound care, tetanus immunization, and close observation, including regular monitoring of vital signs, tissue swelling, and coagulation studies.

answers.content: Application of a tourniquet around the right lower leg
answers.explanation_why: Tourniquets and constrictive dressings are generally not recommended after a snakebite. Though constriction may theoretically delay venom spread through lymphatic channels, there is no evidence that this intervention provides any clinical benefit. Moreover, tourniquets can worsen local ischemia and tissue damage. Oral suction and cutting of the wound should also be avoided in the management of snakebite wounds, as their efficacy has not been proven.

answers.content: Compartment pressure measurement in the right lower leg
answers.explanation_why: Compartment syndrome is a rare complication of snakebites and typically manifests with pulselessness, paresthesia, pallor, and pain on passive stretch. Although this patient presents with limited range of motion of the right knee and ankle due to pain, he has no other symptoms of compartment syndrome. Direct measurement is only indicated in patients with clinical features of increased compartment pressure. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Hospitalization and close observation of coagulation studies over 24 hours
answers.explanation_why: Patients with dry bites (in which no envenomation occurs) or mild envenomation from crotaline snakes can experience localized pain and swelling and should be hospitalized for pain control, local wound care, and close observation, including regular monitoring of vital signs, tissue swelling, and coagulation studies. This patient, however, has systemic features, including nausea, tachycardia, tachypnea, and mild hypotension, which are consistent with envenomation of moderate severity. Moderate to severe envenomation requires active treatment rather than observation alone.

answers.content: Administration of neostigmine and endotracheal intubation
answers.explanation_why: Neurotoxic venom can cause neuromuscular blockade and diaphragmatic paralysis, which require neostigmine administration and intubation. Though some North American snakes have neurotoxic venom (e.g., coral snakes and some rattlesnakes), this patient does not have any neurologic symptoms, which makes acute neurotoxicity less likely. If he were to develop muscle weakness, upper airway obstruction, or significantly altered mental status, neostigmine administration and intubation might be indicated. However, they are not the most appropriate next steps in management at this time.

Hematologic toxicity is a common effect of crotaline envenomation and typically results in abnormalities in coagulation parameters (e.g., prolonged prothrombin time, hypofibrinogenemia, thrombocytopenia), in part due to the activity of thrombin-like glycoproteins from the venom. These glycoproteins are not inhibited by the action of heparin, which plays no role in the management of crotaline envenomation and may increase the risk of bleeding.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 12 years
Sex assigned at birth: F
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: ”My daughter can't get rid of this cough.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought to the office by her mother

10-month history of dry cough and nasal congestion that started in March
symptoms are present nearly every day but are worse during weekdays and improve slightly over the weekend
reports an unrepaired water leak from an air conditioning unit in her classroom and similar symptoms among several classmates

Past Medical History:
no serious illness
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
no similar symptoms in her family
Psychosocial History:

lives with parents, 16-year-old brother, and 1-year-old sister in Florida
participates in the school basketball team; has intensified training since last year, currently practicing 4 afternoons every week;  does 5k runs with her brother on the weekends

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37.1°C
(98.8°F)

82/min
18/min
123/75 mm Hg
98% on RA

155 cm
(5 ft 1 in)
55th %ile

45 kg
(99 lb)
57th %ile

19 kg/m^2
59th %ile

Appearance: alert; intermittent dry cough
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: PERRLA; normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; pale nasal mucosa; hypertrophic turbinates

Pulmonary: scattered expiratory wheezing

Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs; capillary refill < 2 seconds

Extremities: no joint swelling, edema, or tenderness

Diagnostic Studies

spirometry: FEV_1/FVC ratio of 0.65
chest x-ray: no abnormalities

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 12 years Sex assigned at birth: F Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: ”My daughter can't get rid of this cough.” History of Present Illness: patient brought to the office by her mother 10-month history of dry cough and nasal congestion that started in March symptoms are present nearly every day but are worse during weekdays and improve slightly over the weekend reports an unrepaired water leak from an air conditioning unit in her classroom and similar symptoms among several classmates Past Medical History: no serious illness Medications: none Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: no similar symptoms in her family Psychosocial History: lives with parents, 16-year-old brother, and 1-year-old sister in Florida participates in the school basketball team; has intensified training since last year, currently practicing 4 afternoons every week; does 5k runs with her brother on the weekends Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37.1°C(98.8°F) 82/min 18/min 123/75 mm Hg 98% on RA 155 cm(5 ft 1 in)55th %ile 45 kg(99 lb)57th %ile 19 kg/m259th %ile Appearance: alert; intermittent dry cough Skin: no rashes HEENT: PERRLA; normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; pale nasal mucosa; hypertrophic turbinates Pulmonary: scattered expiratory wheezing Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs; capillary refill < 2 seconds Extremities: no joint swelling, edema, or tenderness Diagnostic Studies spirometry: FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65 chest x-ray: no abnormalities Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has features of asthma (persistent dry cough, expiratory wheezing, obstructive pattern on spirometry) and chronic rhinitis (hypertrophic turbinates).
learning_objective: Recognize allergic asthma, and its likely trigger.

answers.explanation_why: Although pollen is a common trigger of allergic asthma and allergic rhinitis, and some pollens (e.g., alder and hazel tree pollen) start to appear as early as March, pollen-induced allergy typically has a seasonal pattern. This patient's symptoms have lasted nearly a year and improve on weekends, which makes another cause more likely.

Inhalation of aerosols from air conditioners (e.g., at school) with water contaminated by Legionella pneumophila, a gram-negative bacteria, can cause outbreaks of legionellosis, which manifests as self-limiting Pontiac fever with flu-like symptoms, or as Legionnaires' disease with atypical pneumonia and additional gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, confusion). This patient has no gastrointestinal or neurological symptoms, and her respiratory symptoms have continued for nearly a year. Furthermore, if this patient had legionellosis, her symptoms would not improve on weekends.

Symptoms of exercise-induced asthma are triggered shortly after the onset of intense exercise and can persist for up to one hour after its completion. Although this patient's symptoms worsen in the afternoons during basketball training, she does not report asthmatic symptoms during her weekend runs.

Allergic asthma, the most common type of asthma, is an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction to specific allergens and is commonly associated with other atopic conditions such as allergic rhinitis. The most frequently implicated allergens include pollen, dust mites, mold, and animal dander. Pollen-induced allergies are typically seasonal, whereas allergies caused by indoor exposure to dust mites, mold, or animal dander are usually perennial and linked to repeated exposure at home, school, or the workplace. Certain species of mold are associated with an increased risk of allergic asthma (e.g., Aspergillus), and exposure to mold spores typically occurs in damp environments (e.g., due to a water leak). Occasionally, especially in colder regions of the U.S., mold-induced allergies may display a seasonal pattern because mold growth increases during periods of heightened moisture. Management of allergic asthma involves stepwise asthma treatment and avoidance of environmental triggers.

Viral upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) can cause an outbreak in a school and is a typical trigger of nonallergic asthma in children. However, viral URTI typically resolves within 1–2 weeks, whereas this patient has had symptoms for nearly a year.

hint: This patient's restrictive lung disease pattern with decreased DL_CO in pulmonary function testing (PFTs) and chest x-ray findings are consistent with interstitial lung disease (ILD). A detailed exposure history is crucial for diagnosis.
learning_objective: Distinguish hypersensitivity pneumonitis from other causes of chronic cough.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is associated with a history of smoking and may manifest with dyspnea, chronic cough, and decreased DL_CO. However, PFTs would reveal an obstructive lung disease pattern with a decreased FEV_1/FVC ratio, while chest x-rays usually show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation rather than fibrotic changes.

Medication-induced lung injury may manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, PFTs showing a restrictive pattern with decreased DL_CO, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. Several medications potentially induce lung injury, including nitrofurantoin, amiodarone, and certain chemotherapeutic agents such as bleomycin, busulfan, and methotrexate. Medication-induced lung injury is not an adverse effect of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin.

Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis can be caused by hay containing Aspergillus spores and may manifest with chronic cough, shortness of breath, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. However, it primarily affects immunocompromised individuals and individuals with previous pulmonary pathologies such as tuberculosis. Symptoms frequently include hemoptysis and recurrent acute pneumonia due to superinfections. Chest x-rays commonly show cavities or aspergillomas adjacent to areas of fibrosis.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) is a combined type III and type IV hypersensitivity reaction caused by inhalation of organic particles, such as animal proteins, microorganisms (e.g., actinomycete spores from moldy hay), and inorganic chemicals (see “Overview of antigens and diseases in hypersensitivity pneumonitis” table). HP is often a result of occupational exposure to these antigens and is a notifiable occupational disease. HP can be acute, manifesting within 12 hours of exposure with flu-like symptoms, dyspnea, and chest tightness; or chronic, manifesting after weeks to years of exposure with progressive dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. The diagnosis of HP is based on a history of antigen exposure, typical clinical and radiological features, and supportive diagnostic studies. PFTs typically show findings of ILD.

A high-resolution CT should be obtained in all patients to classify HP as fibrotic or nonfibrotic, which impacts further workup, treatment, and prognosis. The cornerstone of HP management is antigen avoidance.

Allergic asthma is triggered by allergens such as mold spores, which may be found in hay. It is also associated with atopic dermatitis and typically manifests with cough and dyspnea. However, PFTs in allergic asthma show obstructive lung disease pattern with a reduced FEV_1/FVC ratio and normal or increased DL_CO. Imaging is not routinely recommended for allergic asthma, but chest x-rays are usually normal or may show pulmonary hyperinflation and bronchial wall thickening. Additionally, physical examination is likely to reveal end-expiratory wheezes rather than diffuse crackles.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports that his vision has been progressively worsening over the past several months, and he has also developed numbness and tingling in his feet. Medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is retired and lives in Texas with his wife. He served in the US Army during the Vietnam War. Current medications are metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and jogs outdoors almost daily for 20 minutes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral retinopathy. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution in both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional long-term health risk associated with this patient's history?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment for his type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports that his vision has been progressively worsening over the past several months, and he has also developed numbness and tingling in his feet. Medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease, peripheral neuropathy, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is retired and lives in Texas with his wife. He served in the US Army during the Vietnam War. Current medications are metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and jogs outdoors almost daily for 20 minutes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral retinopathy. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in a stocking-glove distribution in both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional long-term health risk associated with this patient's history?
hint: This patient is at increased risk for conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, which was used in the Vietnam War.
learning_objective: Recognize long-term health risks associated with Agent Orange exposure.

answers.explanation_why: The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs recognizes several conditions associated with Agent Orange exposure, including cancers (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Hodgkin lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma) and noncancer conditions (e.g., type 2 diabetes mellitus, ischemic heart disease, Parkinson disease, peripheral neuropathy). Epidemiological studies have demonstrated an increased incidence of Parkinson disease among soldiers exposed to Agent Orange, which is thought to be due to dioxin-induced neurotoxicity affecting dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Recognizing this association is essential for screening and early intervention.

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) include tobacco products and silica exposure. This patient has no smoking history or relevant silica exposure. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for SLE.

While military service may increase the risk of respiratory diseases through exposure to, e.g., tobacco smoke or burn pits, this patient has no history of smoking or extensive exposure to air pollution or fine dusts. His military service is more likely to have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Environmental factors associated with multiple sclerosis include low vitamin D levels and tobacco products. As this patient exercises outdoors almost daily, vitamin D deficiency is unlikely. Furthermore, he has no smoking history. It is more likely that this patient's military service involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for multiple sclerosis.

Environmental factors associated with an increased risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) include tobacco products and certain occupational or environmental exposures (e.g., lead, pesticides). This patient has no history of smoking or significant occupational exposures known to increase the risk of ALS. His military service may have involved exposure to Agent Orange, which is not a risk factor for ALS.
